title: Tuesday, 25th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hmmmmmmmmmmm .... Do we have a tech snafu?

BE11:04am

Welcome! To Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this thing.

BE11:05am

As is tradition, have a picture.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

© Getty, to emphasise.

BE11:06am

Apropos of: https://www.ft.com...-bc4b-5528796fe35c

11:06 am
BE11:06am

The writers are the first daughter of the US and the president of the World Bank Group

BE11:07am

Yep, that's all totally normal.

BE11:08am

Do give it a read, whatever your opinion is on the author(s).

11:08 am
BE11:09am

You can also sign up via MyFT for Ivanka author alerts, I noticed! (Just don't hold your breath on that triggering too often.)

undefined
BE11:09am

So anyway, Paul's not here.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

He's either been sacked or is in Reuters training, I wasn't really listening.

BE11:10am

So you have me for an hour.

BE11:10am

In a flattish market.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

FTSE going nowhere in particular.

BE11:11am

Up 19 points live, 7283

BE11:11am

Whitbread, clearly, the standout feature.

11:11 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,021, down 286 (-6.64%), High: 4,200, Low: 3,955, Volume: 1.03m
BE11:11am

Costa LFL turns negative

BE11:12am

Or rather, gone to 2.0% vs 3.0% after nine months.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Usual stuff about cautious consumers and wage inflation and etc.

BE11:13am

Citi can summarise the numbers.

BE11:14am

Whitbread reported in-line FY17 results, with revenues +8.2% to £3,106m (Citi £3,135, Cons £3,345) and adj EBIT +4.9% to £592m (Citi £598m, Cons £596m). Adj PBT was +6.2% to £565m (Citi £567m, Cons £560m) and adj EPS +6.0% to 246.48p (Citi 247.2p, Cons 242.9p). DPS was +6.0% to 95.80p and Net debt £890m (FY16 £910m). Implied Q4 trends are broadly in line with PI LFL improving from 1.8% in Q3 to +2.7% in Q4 but Costa weakening from +2.9% to +0.6% (adjusted for the later end to Q3), implying negative volumes.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

We expect little change to consensus. The outlook statement is solid with management expressing “confidence in delivering another year of good progress, in line with overall expectations. Whilst we are only seven weeks into our new financial year Premier Inn has had a good start to the year and Costa has also seen positive like for like sales growth, although we remain cautious and expect a tougher consumer environment than last year”.

BE11:15am

PI and Restaurant LFL sales were +2.3% and -0.3% respectively (Citi +2.5% and 0%), driven by LFL RevPAR -0.6%, weak as expected given the impact of extensions. FY17 PI RevPAR was -0.6%, driven by London - 3.3% and regionals +0.3%. This has reversed in Q4 however with London +1.1% and regionals -0.8% for total Q4 RevPAR of +0.6%. Combined operating profit was +7.4% to £468m (Citi £475m). EBIT margin flat at 24.5% (Citi 24.7%).

BE11:15am

Valuation & View — Buy. We continue to see good roll out potential for both Premier Inn and Costa in the UK and think investors have a free option on the group’s international expansion. Based on our FY18E forecasts the stock trades on c17x PE and c11x EV/EBITDA. European Hotel peer averages of c19x and c12x.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Actually, most of the sellside's pretty chilled.

BE11:17am

Sales weak, shares perhaps run too far.

BE11:17am

Simon French at Cenkos ....

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Overall these numbers will reassure the market and the outlook is pragmatic rather than overtly cautious. The stock has rallied hard into the figures and trades on a CY 2017E P/E of 17.6x and an adj EV/EBITDAR of 10.5x whilst yielding 2.3%. Share price progress from here is likely to be harder to come by.

BE11:18am

......... Bored now.

undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Okay, so Weir (as mentioned on the right ...)

BE11:18am

... is Cazenove pushing.

Weir Group PLC (WEIR:LSE): Last: 2,061, up 58 (+2.90%), High: 2,069, Low: 2,037, Volume: 442.82k
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Whole sector's been doing okay on the back of Schlumberger etc indicating that shale demand has hit a recovery point.

BE11:20am

Fracklog now running down and all that stuff.

BE11:20am

That's the upshot of the JPM note, with mining capex the kicker.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

While demand in Weir’s two main end markets (oil & gas and mining equipment) has been improving for some months, the pace of improvement has been more dynamic than expected. Furthermore, companies that have already reported Q1 have surprised on the upside. Even though demand has been improving, we have remained cautious about price power in the near-term and this may prove to be too conservative. With close to 10% upside potential to our price target and upside risk to our forecasts should the pricing climate improve, we are raising our recommendation to Overweight from Neutral.

BE11:22am

Theme her is that rig count is rising and Weir O&G has done all the cost cutting so is operationally geared into the recovery, meaning a 26% upgrade to operating profit forecasts for 2018.

BE11:23am

Is it odd that analysts seem to view companies "cutting fat" without ever factoring in the idea that, during good times, they'll also add fat? Anyway ...

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Mining side is good aftermarket growth and steady improvement of brownfield developments.

BE11:24am

· Price target raised to 2,175p. On the back of our increased forecasts and based on a 15.0x EV/EBITA multiple, our Dec-17 PT rises to 2,175p from 1,800p. We believe a multiple premium relative to the group historical average is warranted given the prospect of EPS rising by 82% between 2016 and 2018E, and our view of ongoing upside risk to our forecasts.

· Valuation. Based on our forecasts, the group is trading 2018E EV/EBITA and PE multiples of 14.0x and 17.8x, respectively, leaving Weir at a modest premium to our industrial universe, despite the prospect of earnings rising around 4x faster than for the sector overall between ‘16 and ‘18E.

BE11:24am

So, that's Weir.

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

Elsewhere in your FT this morning ....

BE11:25am

This is good: https://www.ft.com...-9ec8-168383da43b7

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Miles Johnson taking apart the "short malls" trade, a favourite of the west coast hedge funds, perhaps in part because it looks rather sub-primey.

BE11:27am

Over the past year there has been a growing amount of evidence to suggest that the financial health of the large tenants of the bigger Reits such as Simon Property and GGP is also dereriorating. Tenants of these large mall operators are generally split between their large “anchor” retailers, big name retailers such as Macy’s and Sears, and then smaller so-called “in-line” tenants who tend to pay higher rents than the flagship stores.

BE11:27am

Mr Clark of Horseman notes how the rent per square foot paid by the specialty “in-line” retailers can sometimes be as much as 30 times that paid by anchor tenants, meaning the fate of these smaller retailers is crucial to the fortunes of the mall operators.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

!!!!

BE11:28am

Some readthrough here for Hammerson, of course ....

Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 602.00, up 7 (+1.18%), High: 604.00, Low: 595.00, Volume: 728.56k
11:29 am
BE11:29am

............. though I'm sure they'll argue that European retail dynamics are rather better, because European cities don't have every town above a 200k population having to have a "good mall" and a "bad mall" on opposite sides of town.

BE11:29am

The other thing I meant to note, while doing internal promotion, was the Responsible Business Awards.

BE11:30am

https://www.ft.com...-a266-12672483791a

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Shortlist out today.

BE11:30am

Well, I say "shortlist" ... It has 92 names on it.

BE11:31am

Diverse too. Mondelez ... GSK .... Barclays .... AirBNB ...... Centrica ..... Greggs ..... KPMG .......

11:31 am
BE11:31am

These are boom times for Responsible Business, clearly.

undefined
BE11:31am

Okay, back to sellside.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Vectura mentioned on the right.

BE11:04am

Most days the answer to that is "probably", but let's rattle on anyway.

BE11:32am

RBC negative today.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Largely for the same reasons Singer was negative yesterday .....

BE11:32am

.... as in, valuation looking stretched.

BE11:33am

(@AM: specifically, I think they have a programme to arrange shelter during natural disasters. Don't ask me though. I have no dog in this fight.)

11:33 am
BE11:34am

You've got the ruling on generic Advair coming next month, which isn't a sure thing by any means.

BE11:34am

Vectura rallied hard on the idea that Mylan getting a full response letter meant it and Hikma would have the whole $2bn a year US market to themselves ....

BE11:35am

.... without giving too much thought to the possibility that Hikma will also get a full response letter.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Anyway, RBC goes 12% and 45% below consensus for 18 and 19 respectively.

BE11:36am

Modelling Vectura has been testing but, with visibility clearer, we are bringing down revenues and profits: FY18E/19E EBITDA now c.12%/45% below consensus. On a relative basis we see better value elsewhere for now and move to UP from SP. We acknowledge that the shares will react well if VR315 approved on May 10, but we are cautious on the outcome and any upside appears priced in to consensus estimates at least.

BE11:36am

Following our model review (year end change etc),
results and review of the outlook we are moving our FY17E/18E/19E revenue and EBITDA down 2.1%/14.4%/18.3% and 8.0%/24.8%/37.6% respectively. We decreased or pushed out revenue expectations on 10 assets, increased 3 and made no changes to 7 (with some bulked together as legacy products/licenses). Whilst revenues are coming down we don't see an 'offset' to R&D spend, which we think is likely to remain high given pipeline commitments and we still see downside to FY19E even with VR315 approval. We note consensus post merger has also come down, but think the outer years still too aggressive.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

They're building in a delay for generic Advair, but needless to say that's with no particular certainty.

BE11:38am

On our valuation we struggle to see shares holding their value unless VR315 is approved or sees only a minor delay. If approved we think shares could reach 150p (+5%) and potentially 180p (+24%) sentiment boost as first to launch. Against our own forecasts, we think consensus is already pricing in much of the benefit. If a delay is confirmed, then we think the shares could rise to 143p (short term delay, 3 strengths approved), but 124p (-20%) if any longer and perhaps, with sentiment, towards our 98p low (-34%, no value for pipeline). We think it best to wait to take a view once approved, delayed, strengths involved etc. given dynamics.

BE11:39am

Important also that, post the Advair call next month, there's nothing on the schedule until 2019.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:41am

Brief pause while I scan emails for the past half hour ....

BE11:41am

.......... and there ain't much.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Luckily, there's sellside to get us though.

BE11:41am

Goldman selling the miners this morning.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,112, down 17 (-1.51%), High: 1,118, Low: 1,099, Volume: 3.09m
11:41 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,208, down 6.5 (-0.54%), High: 1,219, Low: 1,189, Volume: 2.82m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,102, down 10.5 (-0.34%), High: 3,107, Low: 3,071, Volume: 1.14m
BE11:42am

Goldman only turned positive on the sector in November 2016, which one could argue was rather late in the rebound.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Though still managed to get them a 22% return.

BE11:43am

As in, until mid February when it reversed.

BE11:43am

So .........

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Sector view
· Tightening bias emerging from China - 1Q/March data has shown the Chinese economy to be performing well and while the immediate reaction is to see this as validation of a bullish outlook for miners. But a tightening bias has emerged in China rates (the 7/14 day repo rate has inched higher) which has inflected sentiment
· Tougher comps, PPI likely to fade - Yoy comps for key data (e.g. IP, exports) will become tougher heading into 2H. A fading PPI is likely to see the following: 1) behavior of commodity consumers change, i.e. they are likely to move to destocking and 2) A higher PPI is unlikely to result in a big capex drive given supply rationalisation is likely to continue in those sectors.

BE11:44am

Commodity view
· Iron-ore worst positioned - We see IO as having the worst outlook: 1) steel production is running at a high level and 2) exporting excess production could provide challenging with new tariffs in place; and 3) together credit conditions are seeing downward pressure on China steel prices. This together with 1) high IO inventory levels and 2) further production from global seaborne producers and China domestic will likely see IO prices lower.
· Copper – long positioning a risk - The significant speculative position/inventory build post the US election seems to be unwinding. Indicators of physical demand are inconclusive, we believe this could persist, putting further pressure on commodity prices.
· Aluminium – Remains best positioned; China has started to follow up on their promised capacity cuts

BE11:44am

Argument here is that folk still don't like miners.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

We believe market will be unwilling to pay anything more than trough multiples and will likely trade the momentum which is likely to be negative over the near term.

BE11:45am

So, sell nearly everything.

BE11:45am

· Downgrade BHP to Sell: 50% of company’s FY18E EBITDA is derived from iron ore/coal, the outlook for which has turned negative in our view. With earning trajectory negative on GS estimates we see BHP as trading at 7x FY19 EBITDA.
· We add Norsk-Hydro to the Conviction List: aluminium, in our view, remains best positioned commodity, as China manages supply.
· Downgrade Anglo American to Neutral: iron ore prices are set to weaken and we forecast met coal to retreat to ~$150 / t pst cyclone Debbie. We see increasing uncertainty in SA presenting risk around its spin-off plan.
· Downgrade Antofagasta to Sell: Anto remains expensive on GSe trading at

8x EV/EBITDA 2017-19E and we see near-term risks to the copper price if the reflation trade continues to lose steam.

· We remove Vedanta from the Conviction List as in a bearish market, levered name like Vedanta is likely to underperform peers.
· We downgrade Nyrstar to Neutral: a lack of catalysts and pricing power drive this.
· We downgrade Kumba to Sell: iron ore prices are starting to come under pressure and uncertainty in SA puts the spin-off plan at risk.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

(The embedded quote in that extract is the greater-than sign, incidentally. Whoever first specced the Markets Live mark-up language decided to use the greater-than sign to trigger a block quote ....

BE11:46am

.... because what are the chances we'd ever use a greater-than sign in financial reporting?)

BE11:47am

(Coders. SMH.)

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:48am

Straight Path flashes crossing the tape.

BE11:48am

Unsolicited offer of $104.64 per share

11:48 am
BE11:49am

As in, outbidding AT&T.

BE11:49am

Which is given five days to respond.

BE11:50am

Offer "from a multinational telecommunications company" says Straight Path, which seems unnecessarily coy.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Verizon's on the record as having looked.

BE11:51am

And has been talking openly about a need to scale up.

BE11:51am

Sprint, also, has been linked.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Anyway, good to see a bid battle develop -- albeit one that was already anticipated to a fair degree.

undefined
BE11:54am

(@Boncoeur: I'm appointing you our official Unicode correspondent. Please stand ready and await further orders.)

11:54 am
BE11:54am

So ............................ What else?

BE11:55am

Carpetright's had its quarterly profit warning.

Carpetright PLC (CPR:LSE): Last: 232.00, down 13 (-5.31%), High: 239.00, Low: 213.00, Volume: 171.91k
11:55 am
BE11:56am

You see .... the thing with Carpetright is that it sells carpets. I don't know if its investors fully grasp that yet.

BE11:56am

Here's Singer to summarise the latest reminder.

BE11:56am

In the 12 week period to 22 April, Carpetright reports that LFL sales were ahead 1.4% in the UK and 1.4% in Europe. This performance is slightly shy of our expectations due mainly to a weaker trading environment (N+1E +3% and +5% respectively) albeit a further 6% of the UK estate has been refurbished vs prior guidance which will have created a bit of additional drag from disruption in the period and which is positive for FY18 and beyond. Critically, those stores that have annualised new competitor Tapi openings traded well into positive LFL territory, which is a key milestone in the turnaround. Whilst trading this week could change the outcome, FY17 forecasts are likely to be reduced by 4%. Given the accumulating self-help and accelerated refurbs we don’t envisage changing outer year forecasts.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:57am

The recovery plan is delivering. Carpetright now has 188 stores trading in the new brand identity, a marked acceleration from the 120 stores at the end of Q3. Management expects to complete the estate by the end of 2018 calendar year. The refurbished stores continue to outperform the rest of the estate (we understand non-refurbished store LFL sales declined over the period). Average transaction values are up in double digit terms, reflecting increasing penetration of IFC (19% over Easter, noting IFC transactions deliver an average transaction value of greater than £1,300 vs £400 for non-credit transactions). The impact from competitor Tapi has also continued to moderate, with Carpetright’s response to adjacent competitor openings generally faster and more effective. Indeed, the 27 Carpetright stores that have now annualised by more than a year and a quarter against Tapi sites delivered an average of 6% LFL sales growth over Q4.

BE11:58am

(They're shop I think.)

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Profits for 2017E to come in towards the bottom of the range, we downgrade. Management expects profits for the year to come in towards the bottom of the range of analyst forecasts (range £13.9m-£16.2m, PHe and consensus £15.3m). We prudently cut our PBT forecast by £1m to £14.3m, EPS 15.9p to reflect this. While it is disappointing to see further slippage in numbers, there is now a clearer trend in performance coming from the new format stores, which we expect to deliver greater self-help momentum over the year ahead. In terms of store numbers, Carpetright will finish the year trading from 427 stores and concessions in the UK and is on track to reduce this below 400 over the coming year, providing further cost savings.

BE11:59am

"[W]ith 40 per cent of space now in the new format, we may well be at the turning point," says Peel Hunt.

BE11:59am

One can make similar arguments about painting the Forth Bridge. I'd be pretty happy being 40% finished with that.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The evidence does seem to suggest that retail refits never bloody stop though, so I don't quite get why people consider them an exceptional expense.

undefined
BE12:00pm

Hey, look at the time!

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Let's end this farrago. Back tomorrow.

BE12:03pm

Thanks for the comments. Afternoon all.

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 138.93, down 3.67 (-2.57%), High: 141.00, Low: 133.90, Volume: 2.34m
